title: One Direction's Harry Styles urged fans to boycott SeaWorld
text:
4.7k shares 176

comments
A single-sentence criticism of SeaWorld by Harry Styles has led to a surge of anger against the theme park by his fans so powerful that analysts said it's created a 'brand impairment issue'.
During a recent concert in San Diego, home to one of the most popular SeaWorld attractions, the One Direction star asked the crowd: 'Does anybody like dolphins?' When his legion of fans roared their approval, he quickly followed with: 'Don't go to SeaWorld.'
Credit Suisse said that these four words led to a 400 per cent spike in negative comments about the controversial park, already suffering a slump in attendance after a documentary criticised its treatment of killer whales.
Scroll down for video
One Direction's Harry Styles has caused waves of controversy after telling fans to boycott SeaWorld
Following the band's show at Qualcomm Stadium on Thursday, July 9, many fans took to social media to retweet and share the video of Harry's public declaration. Even Game of Thrones' actress Maisie Williams posted the clip to her Instagram page.

Share this article Share 4.7k shares Analysts at Credit Suisse reportedly told SeaWorld that Harry's comments, together with the fact that an employee had infiltrated animal rights protest groups, have sparked a new wave of negative comments online, according to The Guardian .
In a note to clients, Credit Suisse said: 'Brand impairment issues were magnified in July from allegations that a SeaWorld employee acted as an undercover member of activist group Peta, and after One Direction lead singer, Harry Styles, urged all of his fans to boycott SeaWorld during a concert in San Diego.'
During a show in San Diego, the boybander told the crowd 'not go to to SeaWorld' if they 'love dolphins'
Since the July 9 show, analysts at Credit Suisse have warned SeaWorld about 'brand impairment issues' - stemming directly from Harry's controversial remarks last month
The memo said that these incidents had led to a 400 per cent increase in negative online comments about SeaWorld in July this year.
SeaWorld reported an 84 per cent decrease in profits earlier this month.
In response to Harry's on-stage comments, SeaWorld did issue an open letter to the singer on July 15, inviting him to visit one of their parks and speak with their trainers and veterinarians.
Even a month later, One Direction fans are still discussing Harry's controversial concert comments
One Twitter user even added that she didn't want to visit SeaWorld anymore after seeing Harry's video
One fan offered her support by saying that she would 'riot' outside SeaWorld with the One Direction popstar
'We want you to know we love dolphins too,' the letter reads. 'We care for the animals in our parks like we would our own family. We are committed to making sure their lives are enriching and they are continually engaged socially, mentally and physically.
'In fact, SeaWorld has rescued more than 480 whales and dolphins.'
Interestingly, despite Harry's adamant views, his One Direction bandmate, Liam Payne, was photographed swimming with dolphins at Orlando's Discovery Cove, which is a theme park owned and operated by SeaWorld Parks & Entertainment, in 2012.
Interestingly, Harry's bandmate, Liam Payne, was photographed visiting Orlando's Discovery Cove in 2012, which is owned by SeaWorld Parks & Entertainment
SeaWorld has seen a 400% increase in negative comments over the past month, as well as an 84% decrease in profits
And while Credit Suisse has urged SeaWorld to consider new ways to restore the brand's image, SeaWorld's CEO, Joel Manby, has already announced plans for a new company strategy to be put forward in November.
'We realize we have much work ahead of us to recover more of our attendance base, increase revenue and improve our performance as returning to historical performance levels will take time and investment,' he said.
'On the reputation side, early feedback on our campaign has been positive. However, we recognize that fully resolving our brand challenges in California will require sustained focus and commitment to correct misinformation.'
A spokesperson for SeaWorld tells MailOnline Travel: 'It is unfortunate that Mr. Styles has based his opinion of SeaWorld solely on Blackfish. While the truth about our parks is available for anyone to see here, we have extended an invitation to him to visit SeaWorld as our guest to show him the depth of our commitment to these beautiful animals.
'Killer whales at SeaWorld receive world class husbandry and veterinary care and are not just healthy, they are thriving. The opportunity to see killer whales up close has inspired millions of people, especially children, to care more about marine animals, the oceans and the environment.'
Representatives for Harry Styles could not be immediately reached for comment.
Visitor numbers have been sliding at SeaWorld since 2013 when documentary Blackfish was released.
It claimed SeaWorld's treatment of captive orcas provoked violent behaviour in the whales, leading to the deaths of three people.
The company, which operates 11 theme parks across the U.S, reported a profit of $5.8million for April to the end of June - 7 cents per share - which was down from $37.4million for the same period last year.
